text: "After analyzing the information that has been made available by affected power companies, researchers, and the media it is clear that cyber attacks were directly responsible for power outages in Ukraine.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: The SANS ICS team has been coordinating ongoing discussions and providing analysis across multiple international community members and companies.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess with high confidence based on company statements, media reports, and first-hand analysis that the incident was due to a coordinated intentional attack.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text:
"
Read the full SANS post here - and see below for iSIGHT
The SANS ICS blog confirms conclusions previously reached by iSIGHT regarding the nature of the Ukrainian attacks (specifically the role of destructive malware and phone disruption) and attribution to Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: iSIGHT Partners believes this incident is a milestone because it is the first major cyber attack to substantially affect the civilian population and because of the overwhelming importance of the grid to multiple reliant sectors.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, Sandworm Team's previous interest in US and European critical systems underscores the threat they pose (see below for more on Sandworm Team.)
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Since last week, iSIGHT Partners has worked to provide details on the power outage in Ukraine to our global customers.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We have analyzed the forensic evidence we have been able to obtain from the region, contextualizing it within our knowledge of cyber espionage actors.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Many details of the event remain unknown, and given the nature of the incident, especially the use of destructive malware, we do not anticipate every detail will be exposed.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: However, we have linked Sandworm Team to the incident, principally based on BlackEnergy 3, the malware that has become their calling card.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: iSiGHT Partners has tracked Sandworm Team for some time - and we publicly reported on some of their activities in October 2014, when we discovered their use of a zero-day exploit, CVE-2014-4114.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: In that campaign, we saw targeting of Ukrainian government officials, members of the EU and NATO.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Shortly after releasing information on their espionage operations, our friends at TrendMicro found evidence that the operators were not only conducting classic strategic espionage but targeting SCADA systems as well.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Evidence of this accumulated, and iSIGHT Partners released a follow-up blog were we assessed that activity was reconnaissance for attack - a preparation for cyber attack to be carried out in the long term.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text:
ICS-CERT released a separate advisory as well.
Sandworm Team went to ground shortly after being exposed in October of 2014, and malware with Dune references (the genesis for the 'Sandworm' moniker) which we had previously used to track them disappeared entirely.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: However, the unique malware variant, BlackEnergy 3, reemerged in Ukraine early in 2015, where we had first found Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Throughout 2015 we saw increased intrusion activity using BlackEnergy 3.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We warned our clients of new features suggesting an increased focus on European targets - though verification of targets was not possible at the time.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Additionally, we warned our customers about the targeting of both media and regional power authorities in the Ukraine, sectors later affected by cyber attacks.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Some of this information was recently shared by the folks at ESET, who have also been following Sandworm Team very closely for quite some time.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Last week iSIGHT's sources provided us with the same KillDisk malware published by Rob Lee of SANS and Dragos Security.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: As ESET has, we place this malware within the greater context of activity tied to BlackEnergy 3, which we believe is Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We believe this KillDisk malware is related to the destructive malware leveraged during Ukrainian elections in October.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: At the time, CERT-UA connected that incident to BlackEnergy 3.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Symantec has since verified those claims.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, iSIGHT's own sources indicate that BlackEnergy 3 malware was deployed on at least one of the Ukrainian power systems affected by KillDisk.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: iSIGHT Partners is still collecting information on the mechanics of the power outage and what role the KillDisk malware played in the greater event.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We cannot confirm that the KillDisk malware caused the outage.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: It may have been used following steps to manipulate power in order to impede restoration efforts or operator visibility.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: It is noteworthy that technical support numbers associated with the power authorities were allegedly flooded with calls, which may have been an effort to further overwhelm responders.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: On their official website, the Ukrainian security service, SBU, made this claim.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: A cyber attack of this nature is a milestone -although a predictable one.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: The aggressive nature of Sandworm Team's previous activity in Europe and the United States exposed their interest in targeting critical systems and indicated preparation for cyber attack.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Targeting of critical entities in Ukraine throughout 2015, during a time of war, further presaged a desire to disrupt infrastructure.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: On June 27, public announcements were made about a large-scale campaign of ransomware attacks across Europe.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The ransomware impacted notable industries such as Maersk, the world’s largest container shipping company.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The initial infection vector appears to be the exploitation of a Ukrainian tax software called MEDoc.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample also spreads on the internal network via exploitation of the EternalBlue SMB vulnerability, PsExec, WMI, and Admin$ shares.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
The metadata for the analyzed sample is noted below:
Magic: PE32 executable for MS Windows (DLL) (console) Intel 80386 32-bit
Compiled Time: Sun Jun 18 07:14:36 2017 UTC
PE Sections (5): Name       Size       MD5
               + 0x57000    6,008      da2b0b17905e8afae0eaca35e831be9e (Authenticode Signature)
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This sample was compiled recently (18 June 2017 at 07:14:36 UTC) and contains an expired digital signature signed by Microsoft.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This sample utilizes SysInternals PsExec v1.98 for remote execution, with the PsExec digital signature copied and applied to the malware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Initial analysis suggests that the malware is a new variant of the Petya family of ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This recent sample follows the encryption and ransom note functionality seen in Petya samples.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: However, further analysis suggests otherwise, leading to industry concerns of actual attribution and naming, with the colloquial names given of “NotPetya” and “Schrodinger’s Petya.”
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: To understand this, let’s explore some of the more technical components of the ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware itself, a Windows DLL library, is typically saved to the local Windows folder as perfc.dat if it runs with SeDebugPrivilege permission.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If it does not have this privilege, it saves perfc.dat to the All Users application data directory (CSIDL_COMMON_APPDATA) which is resolved by Windows to either C:\ProgramData or “C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data”.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware must be executed with a direct call to its export of ordinal 1, seen as “#1” in the command line.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: There are various reasons why malware tends to use this style of execution, with the most common being to prevent execution within a sandbox.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: A call to the standard DLL export function simply exits.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Upon execution, the malware will begin to perform privilege checking to determine what permissions the running account has, primarily checking for the SeDebugPrivilege permission, as detailed later in User Rights Checking and Malware Logic.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Based upon these privileges the malware will encrypt the victim system in one of two methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If the running user has the SeDebugPrivilege permission, the malware will assume it has administrative privileges, it will then attempt to encrypt the drive using the known Petya code.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is performed by overwriting the Master Boot Record (MBR) of the hard drive (PhysicalDrive0) with malicious code that displays a fake “chkdsk.exe” partition repair screen as it encrypts the hard drive, shown below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is a technique that is known to exist in Petya, using nearly identical text and code.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is the reason why the malware was initially considered to be Petya upon dynamic analysis, although static analysis showed vastly different code for the remainder of the malware’s functionality.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Alternatively, if the user is not running with administrative privileges, as determined by a lack of SeDebugPrivilege, the malware will use a user-space encryption routine, which is a different routine from the one detailed above.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the malware is finished obtaining privileges on the system, it looks for specific processes running on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware authors use a proprietary XOR encryption routine to mask what process names they are looking for.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Carbon Black created a brute force routine to determine what those process names were:
A global variable is modified if these process names are found running on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This global variable affects how the malware runs on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If none of these AV processes are found on the system and the malware obtains the required privileges, the credential stealer is dropped and executed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The presence of these AV’s on the system also affect if the malware runs PsExec, writes to the MBR, the type of encryption used, and if the anti-forensic log clearing is executed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Depending on the return values from this routine and the values SeDebugPrivilege check, if the process context does not have SeDebugPrivilege permissions then the variant will employ a technique common in ransomware variants.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Where files’ data is loaded by using the FindFile and MapViewofFile APIs before encrypting the file’s data.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The file is encrypted in memory using AES encryption and then written to disk when the FlushViewOfFile is called.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the encryption routine completes, the sample will attempt to remove forensic artifacts of its activities by utilizing cmd.exe to run the command listed in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is done after performing additional operating system checks which include ensuring that the system is not version 5.1/5.2 (Windows XP) or 6.1 (Windows 7).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The command will use the wevtutil command to clear (cl) the logs for the Setup, System, Security, and Application event logs.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: It then uses the fsutil command to delete (/D)
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: the USN change journal from the current drive (noted as %c character type).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Before the sample exits it will force a reboot of the infected system using one of three methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The method chosen is dependent upon the context of the process privileges, which are outlined in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will schedule a reboot early in its execution but, depending on the user privileges, will attempt to force a reboot earlier.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: While the initial attack vector of a patient zero is currently unknown, what is known is that the malware is propagated across local environments using several methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Like other recent malware the ransomware utilizes the highly effective EternalBlue exploit for Windows SMB vulnerabilities to copy itself to other systems and execute, which is detailed later in this post.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: In addition to the SMB exploit propagation method, the malware also attempts to establish default administrative network shares (Admin$) with a call to WNetAddConnection2() using a null username and password.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: By using null for these two values, the network connection is made using the current user’s credentials, which directly affect organizations with shared local administrator accounts.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Additionally, if the malware was somehow executed by a domain administrator, these connections would be made even without a shared local administrator account.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
An example of this additional lateral movement attempt is below:
If a connection is made to the remote system, the malware will create a copy of itself directly on the other system using standard CreateFile() and WriteFile() API routines.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware also has the ability to extract an embedded and compressed resource (resource 3) containing the SysInternals PsExec.exe utility.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The psexec.exe file is written to disk as dllhost.dat.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This utility is then used to execute this file on the remote system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Failing that, the malware will then leverage the existing Windows WMI utility to execute the file on the remote system, which is displayed in the image below:
As noted earlier, upon initial execution the sample will check several system privileges to determine the appropriate execution path.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If the process has SeDebugPrivilege it will, among other things, access the physical drive (highlighted in red below) and then initiate a scan that will enumerate other systems on the domain (area highlighted in green in the image below).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The area highlighted in red below shows where a function (labeled here as filename_check) is called, where the sample will check to see if the file C:\Windows\perfc is present on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If present, the process will exit, which is leading many to call this a “kill switch” in the ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This was most likely done to ensure that ransomware was not installed and executed twice on a system, much in the same way a mutex or a file lock (Linux based), is used to prevent multiple instances from running on a system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Code responsible for this process is shown below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The second function (labeled Check_access_and_physicaldisk_Modify) is responsible for attempting to access the physical disk, and then gather drive geometry about the disk itself.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will then make modifications to the MBR.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the alterations have completed the sample will remove forensic artifacts in the manner detailed in Table 1 above, and then shut down as described in Table 2 above.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The function (highlighted in green in the image above) will gather system information and then enumerate the other systems on the domain.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

Decoded Strings used in SMB Exploitation
If the sample finds an exploitable system, it will perform in the same manner that existing ransomware acted by passing a shellcode payload to the target system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

This sample looks for three different types of privileges to perform its actions:

text:
The values are added together using Boolean OR commands which can result in the following results:
Based upon the overall values constructed from these checks, the malware will perform varying sets of routines.

text: Most notably are the methods for which to encrypt files on the system and in rebooting the system after infection.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If the variant detects that its process is running with SeDebugPrivilege privileges it will call a function that is highlighted in red in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware contains four separate, compressed resources that are used as additional commands to execute during operation.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This function will initially attempt to determine if the operating system is either x86 or 64-bit and then it will either load a password dumper from either Resource “1” or “2” (which ultimately are x86 and 64-bit executable files respectively).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: It should be noted that all of the four resources are stored as compressed buffers that can be inflated with zlib.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Each resource contains a DWORD value at offset 0 that is the length of the data once it is inflated.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Once the OS type has been determined and the appropriate resource loaded, the sample will write the executable to the system %TEMP% path with a OS-generated temporary file name (highlighted in red in the image below).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will then create a named pipe to the temporary file (highlighted in blue), and execute the file as a new process, with a parameter of the named pipe (highlighted in green).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This will allow the sample to get the results of the credential harvester.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Once completed the sample will delete the temporary file from the disk.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html
